H0.text: A metallic bond is the force of attraction between a positively charged metal ion and the valence electrons it shares with other ions of the metal.

H1.text: Ionic bond is the force of attraction between a positively charged metal ion and the valence electrons it shares with other ions of the metal.

H2.text: Metallic yield is the force of attraction between a positively charged metal ion and the valence electrons it shares with other ions of the metal.

H3.text: Temporal bond is the force of attraction between a positively charged metal ion and the valence electrons it shares with other ions of the metal.

A4.text: Metallic bonding is a type of chemical bonding that arises from the electrostatic attractive force between conduction electrons (in the form of an electron cloud of delocalized electrons) and positively charged metal ions.

A5.text: Metallic bonding accounts for many physical properties of metals, such as strength, ductility, thermal and electrical resistivity and conductivity, opacity, and lustre.
